titlestmt.titleproper: F.P. Leavenworth Confederate ordnance book, Inclusive: 1862-1865, Bulk: 1864

note.p: © 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: This collection contains an order book written by F.P. Leavenworth during his command of the Confederate arsenal in Shreveport, Louisiana, and ordnance depot in Jefferson, Texas.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Frederick Peabody Leavenworth was born in 1833 to Abner Johnson Leavenworth (1803-1869) of Petersburg, Virginia. At the time of his enlistment in the Confederate army in 1862, F.P. Leavenworth was in Van Buren, Arkansas. Appointed as captain in the Ordnance Department of the Trans-Mississippi in 1863, Leavenworth serves as commander of the Confederate arsenal in Shreveport, Louisiana, 1863-1864. At that time, Shreveport was headquarters of the Trans-Mississippi Department and a major military supply depot for Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, and Missouri. After the fall of Shreveport, Leavenworth moved to Jefferson, Texas, to command the rapidly expanding ordnance supply depot there. He was there to surrender his facility at the end of the Civil War in 1865. After the war, he became an engineer in charge of materials for the Marshall Railroad. He and his wife Eliza Leavenworth had one daughter, Hester Leavenworth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains an order book kept by F.P. Leavenworth in the course of his work as an ordnance officer in the Confederate army, Department of Trans-Mississippi. The bound volume contains a variety of orders, receipts, notifications, and lists pertaining to running the ordnance complex at Shreveport, Louisiana, and Jefferson, Texas. Thorough lists of supplies needed for building a smithy, sawmill, officer’s quarters, and more in Jefferson are recorded.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The F.P. Leavenworth Confederate ordnance book is arranged in one series: I. Confederate Order Book.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: F.P. Leavenworth Confederate ordnance book, Accession #4025, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Paul T. Fisher. Released on 2017-07-13.
Archivist''s Notes: Names of Confederate officers in the order book
Lieutenant Colonel Gabriel Hill (Commanding Officer, Tyler Ordnance Works),
Major T.G. Rhett (Chief, Ordnance and Artillery, Shreveport Department),
Captain C.W. Wailey (Commanding Officer, Shreveport Arsenal),
Major G.D. Alexander (Commanding Officer, Marshall Arsenal).

controlaccess.head: Subjects (Organizations)
controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army -- Ordnance and ordnance stores.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains the order book of F.P. Leavenworth, ordnance officer in the Confederate army. It contains various orders and lists pertaining to running the ordnance complex at Shreveport, Louisiana, and Jefferson, Texas.
